title: ED-SAFE Patient Safety Screener 3 (PSS-3)
description: Screens for suicidality in emergency patients through universal screening with a validated 3-question tool. Designed for rapid assessment of suicide risk in the emergency department setting for patients with any chief complaint.

parameters.name: depression_past_2_weeks
parameters.description: Over the past 2 weeks, have you felt down, depressed, or hopeless?

parameters.name: suicidal_thoughts_past_2_weeks
parameters.description: Over the past 2 weeks, have you had thoughts of killing yourself?

parameters.name: lifetime_suicide_attempt
parameters.description: Have you ever in your lifetime made a suicide attempt?

result.name: pss3_result
result.description: PSS-3 screening result indicating suicide risk level

ranges.interpretation: Negative screen for suicide risk. No current suicidal ideation or lifetime suicide attempt reported. Continue with routine emergency care. Consider documenting negative screen in medical record.

Positive screen for suicide risk. Patient has active suicidal ideation in past 2 weeks OR lifetime history of suicide attempt. Requires immediate further assessment by treating clinician. Consider mental health consultation, safety planning, and risk stratification with ED-SAFE Secondary Screener (ESS-6) if available.

references: Boudreaux ED, Camargo CA Jr, Arias SA, Blais RK, Horton BJ, Jaques ML, et al. Improving Suicide Risk Screening and Detection in the Emergency Department. Am J Prev Med. 2016;50(4):445-453. doi: 10.1016/j.amepre.2015.09.029.

Boudreaux ED, Jaques ML, Brady KM, Matson A, Allen MH. The patient safety screener: validation of a brief suicide risk screener for emergency department settings. Arch Suicide Res. 2015;19(2):151-60. doi: 10.1080/13811118.2015.1034604.

Miller IW, Camargo CA Jr, Arias SA, Sullivan AF, Allen MH, Goldstein AB, et al. Suicide prevention in an emergency department population: the ED-SAFE study. JAMA Psychiatry. 2017;74(6):563-570. doi: 10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2017.0678.

Boudreaux ED, Miller I, Goldstein AB, Sullivan AF, Allen MH, Manton AP, et al. The Emergency Department Safety Assessment and Follow-up Evaluation (ED-SAFE): method and design considerations. Contemp Clin Trials. 2013;36(1):14-24. doi: 10.1016/j.cct.2013.05.008.
formula: PSS-3 positive screening if: (1) Active suicidal ideation in past 2 weeks (Question 2 = Yes) OR (2) Lifetime history of suicide attempt (Question 3 = Yes). Depression question (Question 1) contributes to clinical context but does not independently determine positive screening.
notes: Developed as part of the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) ED-SAFE study.
Validated for universal screening in emergency departments for patients ≥18 years old.
Can be administered to patients with any chief complaint, including non-psychiatric presentations.
Strong agreement with Beck Scale for Suicide Ideation (BSSI): κ = 0.94-0.95 for overall screening.
Doubles the rate of suicide risk detection compared to routine clinical assessment (from 2.9% to 5.7%).
Administered during triage or primary nursing assessment for rapid screening.
Positive screen requires further assessment by treating clinician and consideration of mental health consultation.
Among patients with non-psychiatric chief complaints, 3-12% also have suicidal ideation.
Part of comprehensive ED-SAFE protocol which includes secondary screening (ESS-6) and safety planning.
Should be used as universal screening tool for all ED patients, not just those with psychiatric presentations.
Brief tool designed for fast-paced emergency department environment.
Positive screening patients should receive safety planning and risk stratification.
Question 1 (depression) provides clinical context but is not required for positive screening determination.
Validation study demonstrated fair agreement for ideation detection (κ = 0.61) and excellent agreement for suicide attempts (κ = 0.97-0.98).
Tool can identify at-risk patients who might otherwise go undetected in emergency care.
Should be followed by comprehensive suicide risk assessment if screening is positive.
Documentation of screening results important for continuity of care and quality improvement.
Cost-effective screening approach that fits into existing ED workflow.
